citations.narrative:
Two rabbits housed in a stall within the barn managed to escape their primary enclosure by digging into the floor next to
the wall and creating a gap that allowed them to enter the hollow space in the wall between the stall and an adjacent tack
room. Before entering the enclosure, the facility representative stated that during their morning check, one of the rabbits
was missing and they identified the hole in the enclosure. They stated that they believed the rabbit was in the hole. When
entering the enclosure, neither rabbit was present or able to be observed. They stated that now they believed both of the
rabbits were in the hole, and they had plans to set a live trap to recover the animals that evening. Rabbits that can escape
their primary enclosures can become injured, trapped, or lost, leading to unnecessary pain and distress. Correct by 15
June 2024 by ensuring all primary enclosures are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the rabbits
from injury, to contain them, and to keep predators out.

Three primary enclosures housing a total of three sheep and nine goats have several areas in disrepair. A goat pen
housing three goats has a ramp approximately 1.5 feet wide leading to a catwalk. The ramp is constructed with horizontal
cleats of wood to help with footing. One cleat has broken off, leaving sharp screws sticking up through the ramp floor.
Another missing cleat has exposed one screwhead projecting up from the ramp floor. The facility representative states
that the goats use the ramp and platform regularly. A wire fence panel between another two enclosures, one housing
three goats and one housing three sheep, has several areas of a cross wire that have broken off, leaving sharp wires
protruding from the fence line into the enclosures. Finally, on one wooden fence a wooden board has broken and fallen
off, leaving nails exposed where the board was attached to the cross posts. Sharp edges created by protruding nails,
screws, and wire into animal enclosures can lead to animal injuries. Correct by ensuring all facilities are maintained in
good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain the animals securely.

The facility does not have an effective pest control program in place to control the fly population in the barn. There are
three stalls in the barn, housing three young goats, five young pigs, four newly hatched chickens, and two rabbits. In each
stall, many flies were sitting on the ground among the bedding. When inspectors stepped in the stalls to inspect, large
numbers of flies flew off the ground. The facility has some fly traps present in the barn but none are near the stalls
housing these animals. Uncontrolled pest populations can lead to spread of diseases and animal discomfort. Correct by 4
July 2024 by ensuring the facility maintains a safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and
avian and mammalian pests.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Shoshana Tanenbaum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Samantha Talley, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.53(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Two rabbits housed in a stall within the barn managed to escape their primary enclosure by digging into the floor next to 
the wall and creating a gap that allowed them to enter the hollow space in the wall between the stall and an adjacent tack 
room. Before entering the enclosure, the facility representative stated that during their morning check, one of the rabbits 
was missing and they identified the hole in the enclosure. They stated that they believed the rabbit was in the hole. When 
entering the enclosure, neither rabbit was present or able to be observed. They stated that now they believed both of the 
rabbits were in the hole, and they had plans to set a live trap to recover the animals that evening. Rabbits that can escape 
their primary enclosures can become injured, trapped, or lost, leading to unnecessary pain and distress. Correct by 15 
June 2024 by ensuring all primary enclosures are structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the rabbits 
from injury, to contain them, and to keep predators out. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
Three primary enclosures housing a total of three sheep and nine goats have several areas in disrepair. A goat pen 
housing three goats has a ramp approximately 1.5 feet wide leading to a catwalk. The ramp is constructed with horizontal 
cleats of wood to help with footing. One cleat has broken off, leaving sharp screws sticking up through the ramp floor. 
Another missing cleat has exposed one screwhead projecting up from the ramp floor. The facility representative states 
that the goats use the ramp and platform regularly. A wire fence panel between another two enclosures, one housing 
three goats and one housing three sheep, has several areas of a cross wire that have broken off, leaving sharp wires 
protruding from the fence line into the enclosures. Finally, on one wooden fence a wooden board has broken and fallen 
off, leaving nails exposed where the board was attached to the cross posts. Sharp edges created by protruding nails, 
screws, and wire into animal enclosures can lead to animal injuries. Correct by ensuring all facilities are maintained in 
good repair to protect the animals from injury and contain the animals securely. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
The facility does not have an effective pest control program in place to control the fly population in the barn. There are 
three stalls in the barn, housing three young goats, five young pigs, four newly hatched chickens, and two rabbits. In each

stall, many flies were sitting on the ground among the bedding. When inspectors stepped in the stalls to inspect, large 
numbers of flies flew off the ground. The facility has some fly traps present in the barn but none are near the stalls 
housing these animals. Uncontrolled pest populations can lead to spread of diseases and animal discomfort. Correct by 4 
July 2024 by ensuring the facility maintains a safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and 
avian and mammalian pests. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Shoshana Tanenbaum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Samantha Talley, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
